title: How does alcohol make you drunk? - Judy Grisel

title: Your brain hallucinates your conscious reality - Anil Seth

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's personal experience with anesthesia like?

options.label: A
options.text: The speaker feels a sense of detachment and falling apart.

options.label: B
options.text: The speaker feels a sense of joy and happiness.

options.label: C
options.text: The speaker feels a sense of time passing slowly.

options.label: D
options.text: The speaker feels a sense of being asleep.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's main argument about the nature of consciousness?

options.label: A
options.text: Consciousness is solely a product of intelligence.

options.label: B
options.text: Consciousness is a result of being a living and breathing organism.

options.label: C
options.text: Consciousness is solely a product of the brain.

options.label: D
options.text: Consciousness is solely a product of the body.

multiple-choice.question: What is the brain's best guess of what's out there in the world based on?

options.label: A
options.text: Only sensory signals from the outside world.

options.label: B
options.text: A combination of sensory signals and prior expectations.

multiple-choice.question: What is the Kanizsa triangle an example of?

options.label: A
options.text: A visual illusion that demonstrates how the brain generates its best guess of what's there.

options.label: B
options.text: A visual illusion that demonstrates how the brain is deceived by sensory signals.

options.label: C
options.text: A visual illusion that demonstrates how the brain combines sensory signals with prior expectations.

options.label: D
options.text: A visual illusion that demonstrates how the brain perceives the world.

multiple-choice.question: What is the rubber hand illusion an example of?

options.label: A
options.text: A visual illusion that demonstrates how the brain perceives the world.

options.label: B
options.text: A tactile illusion that demonstrates how the brain generates its best guess of what's there.

options.label: C
options.text: A tactile illusion that demonstrates how the brain combines sensory signals with prior expectations.

options.label: D
options.text: A tactile illusion that demonstrates how the brain perceives the body.

multiple-choice.question: What is interoception?

options.label: A
options.text: The perception of the external state of the body.

options.label: B
options.text: The perception of the internal state of the body.

options.label: C
options.text: The perception of the external world.

options.label: D
options.text: The perception of the internal world.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main implication of the speaker's argument about the nature of consciousness?

options.label: A
options.text: Our individual self and worlds are unique to each of us, but they're all grounded in biological mechanisms shared with many other living creatures.

options.label: B
options.text: Our conscious experiences are solely a product of intelligence.

options.label: C
options.text: Our conscious experiences are solely a product of the brain.

options.label: D
options.text: Our conscious experiences are solely a product of the body.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's argument about the possibility of a conscious AI?

options.label: A
options.text: The speaker thinks that the prospects for a conscious AI are pretty remote.

options.label: B
options.text: The speaker thinks that the prospects for a conscious AI are very high.

options.label: C
options.text: The speaker thinks that the possibility of a conscious AI is solely a product of intelligence.

options.label: D
options.text: The speaker thinks that the possibility of a conscious AI is solely a product of the brain.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between perception and regulation of the internal state of the body?

options.label: A
options.text: Perception is about figuring out what's there, while regulation is about controlling and regulating things.

options.label: B
options.text: Perception is about controlling and regulating things, while regulation is about figuring out what's there.

options.label: C
options.text: Perception and regulation are the same thing.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's final message about the nature of consciousness?

options.label: A
options.text: There's nothing to be afraid of when the end of consciousness comes.

options.label: B
options.text: We should be afraid of losing our consciousness.

options.label: C
options.text: Our consciousness is solely a product of intelligence.

options.label: D
options.text: Our consciousness is solely a product of the brain.

title: What’s a squillo, and why do opera singers need it? Ming Luke

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason an opera singer's voice can be heard so clearly above the strains of dozens of instruments?

options.label: A
options.text: The singer's voice is amplified by a microphone.

options.label: B
options.text: The singer's voice has a unique sonic signature that stands out from the orchestra.

options.label: C
options.text: The singer's voice produces a higher frequency than the instruments.

options.label: D
options.text: The singer's voice is able to project sound due to the physics of the voice and their carefully honed technique.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the lowest vibration in a note, which is what our ears mostly use to identify a note?
How do opera singers work their magic to produce their power of projection?

options.label: A
options.text: By modifying the shape and tension in their vocal folds and vocal tract.

options.label: B
options.text: By shifting the position of their tongues and lips.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the distinctive ringing timbre that opera singers produce by emphasizing the partials in the 2,000-5,000 vibrations per second range?
Why do human ears tend to be more strongly attuned to frequencies between 2,000 and 5,000 vibrations per second?

options.label: A
options.text: Because these frequencies are more common in nature.

options.label: B
options.text: Because these frequencies are easier to produce.

options.label: C
options.text: Because these frequencies are more sensitive to human hearing.

options.label: D
options.text: Because these frequencies are more pleasing to the ear.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the musical effect in which a note slightly oscillates in pitch?
What is the primary function of the vocal tract in an opera singer's voice production?

options.label: C
options.text: To modify the shape and tension in the vocal folds.

multiple-choice.question: How do opera singers increase their range of partials?

options.label: A
options.text: By modifying the shape and tension in their vocal folds and vocal tract.

options.label: B
options.text: By shifting the position of their tongues and lips.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the process of adjusting the airflow to produce a consistent, controlled sound?
How do the acoustic properties of a concert hall affect an opera singer's sound?

options.label: C
options.text: By reflecting sound waves towards the audience.
